This simply isn't true. 

Mages that have assassin levels of damage still aren't assassins,  but even if they were those mages wouldn't be supports. 

When you complain about mages being assassins you have a few types:
Like leblanc,  who is actually an assassin. 
Like Syndra,  who isn't an assassin because while her damage is better she has no reliable way to apply it unless you just walk in to her range. 
Like ahri,  who isn't an assassin because she can't 100-0 a squishy that's a level behind her and has no mr unless she's extremely fed (i.e. she lacks the damage to 100-0 in one combo,  she either needs to be ahead,  needs you sub-60%, or needs to use two or more spell rotations meaning it's not an assassination given that's at least a 5 second cooldown between). 
Note that no one would call any of these supports  - people will typically tilt if you try these. 

When you complain about supports you have a few types :
Annie who's weird,  but may sort of be both. She's flexible. Still very immobile though. Although tibbers is busted
Like brand/zyra who aren't really supports so much as a second apc with sufficient base damage to bully a duo Lane without gold (these guys clearly aren't assassins though)
Like Lulu/Lux who have plenty of supportive spells and transition to damage if wanted - but again clearly aren't assassins. 

So who exactly is both an assassin and a support? My list is 1 long - Annie, and only when she has flash up.

Well sure, but if you want to take that approach then the argument is trivial:
Is there any champion with the combination:
Mage, Assassin, Support?

Clearly there isn't, because Riot only lists two roles.

Now, as to Ahri specifically:
These definitions haven't been changed for ages. Pre 5.2 Ahri WAS an assassin, hence that title. Her charm gave 20% damage amplification and allowed her to 100-0 squishy targets. Post 5.2 Ahri is no longer an assassin by definition. She can be built like one (at least when ahead), but nonetheless she's no longer an assassin but "an ultra-mobile kite mage."

As Riot said themselves in patch 5.2 notes:
"Fantastic Ms. Ahri's success as a support-killing, pick-making assassin has always been tied very closely with Deathfire Grasp. With the item gone, however, it became obvious that Ahri's unique role in the game was losing focus, so we set out with the goal of moving her back to her original vision as an ultra-mobile kite mage. Technical improvements and updates to Fox-Fire and Spirit Rush should make her feel smoother to play, while Orb of Deception's new mobility effect allows her to both outwit opponents in close duels or remain elusive as she repositions in a fight."

As to your definition of assassin, you're largely right. They need the ability to 100-0 though. No one would play an assassin if all they could do is 100 - 10 their victims; they need to be able to finish them. I mean, even though an assassin by definition has the mobility / stealth to get in and out, they are still taking a risk by going in that they will get locked down and killed. Why take that risk if the reward doesn't measure up?

Taken from the "assassin" wiki:
"An assassin is an agile champion that specializes in killing or disabling high value targets. Focused on infiltration, deception, and mobility, assassins are opportunistic hunters who find favorable moments within a fight before jumping into the fray. Regardless of the size of the enemy team, assassins specialize in positioning and artful killing. They strike when the time is right – no sooner, no later."

My definition of assassin at least is the ability to 100-0 a squishy paired with the ability to get in and out despite other non-squishy enemies nearby (if the squishy slightly mispositions, etc...). Most "mage assassins" that the OP is complaining about lack the latter point (ability to get in and out), while some miss the former. I suppose I'm missing the disabling part, but with the amount of lifesteal on ADCs I don't think you can disable one unless you kill it...

I like a lot of your points, and its true that Ahri did lose a fair bit with the damage amp removal. She did get some AP scaling and base damage buffs, and her Q MS buff  for compensation. Still laning against her vs say a Talon or Zed? You people are going to act like Ahri doesnt have a poke, poke, poke GAP CLOSING ALL IN! play pattern like them? Really? If Zed or Talon are behind, they 100-10 a target... I guess that means theyre not assassins if they fall behind.

Anyway, nice points, but we have to be careful with having our "own definitions" as to what stuff is. That just leads to "LALALA I CANT HEAR YOU" moments in discussions.

"An assassin is an agile champion that specializes in killing or **disabling** high value targets. Focused on infiltration, deception, and **mobility**, assassins are **opportunistic** hunters who find favorable moments within a fight before jumping into the fray. Regardless of the size of the enemy team, assassins specialize in positioning and artful killing. They strike when the **time is right** – no sooner, no later."


Ahri development:

By Ryan 'Morello' Scott

Greetings Summoners!

Back in the end of September, we announced The Nine Tails Fox much to the excitement of our community. Well the time has finally come and after much anticipation, we wanted to reveal the gameplay style for Ahri, the Nine-Tailed Fox.

Ahri Ahri's gameplay style revolves around **mobility** and managing position to aim her spells. When played properly, Ahri darts around teamfights, picking off wounded stragglers and harrying soft enemies.

This is largely accomplished through her Spirit Rush ultimate, which allows her to dash multiple times before going on cooldown. Ahri can either use all three quickly to chase, burst, or escape, or she can spread out their uses to keep enemies guessing and juke around the battlefield. Combining this with her high magic damage and her Charm ability to **lock enemies down**, she can strike from unexpected angles or bait enemies into over-committing to disadvantageous situations.

Ahri's major gameplay decisions are based on her **assessment of risk/reward**. Her burst is high, but must be in short range to maximize it. This creates a dynamic that requires her to endanger herself to reach full potential. Play it safe and have more light damage, or commit and go for the kill? Use your dash for damage, or save it for escape? The choices are constant with these opposed strengths and weaknesses.

Her kit is really designed to appeal towards **opportunistic** players who prefer characters with a lot of action, and especially players that like to lull enemies into overconfidence, only to capitalize and punish them. Ahri's dangerous, seductive nature is something we're happy to deliver for players who like to toy with their enemies before destroying them.

___________________________________________________________

I know what the wiki says for assassins, and Ahri plays like an assassin. She has every trait, all the assassin hallmarks. Yeah her damage took a hit, but they replaced it with a truckload of mobility. If shes so much of a kite mage, why does it feel like a kite that is trying to catch up with you to kill you!? Hashtag: Murder Kite (in theaters this summer). Like an assassin, when she decides its time to go in, she does so with damage dealing-gap-closers like Talon and Zed. Looks like a duck, sounds like a duck, albeit a slightly less muscular duck, still pretty ducky... Im going with duck... an assassin duck... note to Rito, new champ needs to be an anthropomorphic assassin duck.

Well if all that didnt sway anyone, and the addition of assassin ducks wasnt slightly funny, then Im done. You guys can take your "ultra mobile kite mage" and have it. Im not calling her an assassin just cause of the label in the client, but also because her playstyle hasnt changed that much.
